CHEMISTRY.content:
THE UNITED REPUBLIC OF TANZANIA
NATIONAL EXAMINATIONS COUNCIL OF TANZANIA
FORM FOUR NATIONAL ASSESSMENT
032 CHEMISTRY
(Theory Paper)
Time: 2:30 Hours

Instructions:
1. Answer all questions in sections A and B.
2. In section C, answer only one question.
3. All answers must be written in the spaces provided.
4. Show all working clearly.
5. Calculators and mobile phones are not allowed.
6. Write your Assessment Number at the top right corner of every page.

SECTION A (15 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

1. For each of the items (i)–(x), choose the correct answer from among the given alternatives and write its letter beside the item number.

   (i) Which of the following elements is a halogen?
   - A. Sodium
   - B. Chlorine
   - C. Oxygen
   - D. Calcium

   (ii) The mass of one mole of an element is called
   - A. Relative atomic mass
   - B. Atomic number
   - C. Molar mass
   - D. Avogadro number

   (iii) Which type of reaction is represented by: Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl2 + H2?
   - A. Decomposition
   - B. Displacement
   - C. Combination
   - D. Neutralization

   (iv) The gas produced when a carbonate reacts with acid is
   - A. Oxygen
   - B. Carbon dioxide
   - C. Hydrogen
   - D. Nitrogen

   (v) The formula of magnesium sulfate is
   - A. MgSO4
   - B. MgS
   - C. MgSO3
   - D. Mg2SO4

   (vi) The correct electronic configuration of oxygen (atomic number 8) is
   - A. 1s2 2s2 2p4
   - B. 1s2 2s4 2p2
   - C. 1s2 2s2 2p6
   - D. 1s2 2p6

   (vii) A covalent bond is formed by
   - A. Transfer of electrons
   - B. Sharing of electrons
   - C. Electrostatic attraction
   - D. Hydrogen bonding

   (viii) Which of the following is a strong acid?
   - A. H2CO3
   - B. HCl
   - C. CH3COOH
   - D. H2O

   (ix) Water acts as a solvent because
   - A. It is non-polar
   - B. It is polar
   - C. It reacts with metals
   - D. It has high density

   (x) Which of the following is a redox reaction?
   - A. NaOH + HCl → NaCl + H2O
   - B. Zn + CuSO4 → ZnSO4 + Cu
   - C. BaCl2 + Na2SO4 → BaSO4 + 2NaCl
   - D. H2O → H2 + O2

2. Match the items in List A with List B.

   List A
   (i) Solubility
   (ii) Volatility
   (iii) Catalyst
   (iv) Electrolysis
   (v) Relative molecular mass

   List B
   A. Mass of a molecule compared to 1/12 of carbon-12 atom
   B. Ability of a substance to dissolve in a solvent
   C. Tendency of a liquid to vaporize
   D. Substance that speeds up a reaction without being consumed
   E. Decomposition of a substance using electricity

SECTION B (70 Marks)
Answer all questions in this section.

3. (a) Define isotopes and give one example.
   (b) An element has two isotopes: 35Cl (abundance 75%) and 37Cl (abundance 25%). Calculate its relative atomic mass.

4. (a) Define ionic and covalent compounds.
   (b) Draw dot and cross diagram for ammonia (NH3).

5. (a) Define molarity and mole fraction.
   (b) Calculate the number of moles in 18 g of water.

6. (a) Explain the Bronsted-Lowry theory of acids and bases.
   (b) Calculate the pH of a solution with [OH-] = 1 × 10^-3 M.

7. (a) Describe factors affecting solubility of solids in liquids.
   (b) 20 g of NaOH is dissolved in 100 g of water. Calculate the mass percentage of NaOH.

8. (a) Define oxidation and reduction with one example each.
   (b) Determine the oxidation number of Cr in K2Cr2O7.

9. (a) Explain electrolysis of aqueous copper (II) sulfate using copper electrodes.
   (b) State the products formed at the cathode and anode.

10. (a) Explain how to prepare 250 cm³ of 1 M HCl from concentrated HCl (12 M).
     (b) State two precautions when handling concentrated acids.

SECTION C (15 Marks)
Answer only one question.

11. (a) Describe the steps to standardize a sodium hydroxide solution using oxalic acid and phenolphthalein indicator.
     (b) Write the reaction equation.
     (c) Explain how the titre readings are used to calculate the concentration of NaOH.

CAnswers2.content:
SECTION A

1. Multiple choice answers (with explanation)

(i) B. Chlorine — Chlorine is a halogen, group 17 element.
(ii) C. Molar mass — Mass of one mole of an element or compound.
(iii) B. Displacement — Zinc displaces hydrogen from HCl.
(iv) B. Carbon dioxide — Carbonate + acid produces CO2.
(v) A. MgSO4 — Magnesium sulfate has one Mg²⁺ and one SO4²⁻.
(vi) A. 1s2 2s2 2p4 — Oxygen has 8 electrons.
(vii) B. Sharing of electrons — Covalent bond involves sharing.
(viii) B. HCl — Strong acid fully dissociates in water.
(ix) B. It is polar — Water’s polarity allows it to dissolve many substances.
(x) B. Zn + CuSO4 → ZnSO4 + Cu — Zn is oxidized, Cu²⁺ reduced; redox reaction.

2. Matching

(i) B; (ii) C; (iii) D; (iv) E; (v) A

Explanation:
- Solubility: ability to dissolve.
- Volatility: tendency to vaporize.
- Catalyst: speeds up reaction.
- Electrolysis: decomposition by electricity.
- Relative molecular mass: mass compared to 1/12 of carbon-12.

SECTION B

3. Isotopes

(a) Isotopes: atoms of the same element with same number of protons but different neutrons. Example: 12C, 13C.
(b) RAM = (75 × 35 + 25 × 37)/100 = (2625 + 925)/100 = 3550/100 = 35.5.

4. Ionic vs covalent compounds

(a) Ionic: formed by transfer of electrons, metal + non-metal.
    Covalent: formed by sharing of electrons, non-metal + non-metal.
(b) Dot and cross NH3: N has 5 valence electrons (dots), each H shares 1 electron (cross) → 3 N–H bonds, 1 lone pair on N.

5. Mole concept

(a) Molarity = moles of solute / volume of solution (L). Mole fraction = moles of component / total moles.
(b) Number of moles = mass / molar mass = 18 / 18 = 1 mole.

6. Acids and bases

(a) Brønsted-Lowry: Acid = proton donor, Base = proton acceptor.
(b) [H+] = Kw / [OH-] = 1 × 10^-14 / 1 × 10^-3 = 1 × 10^-11 → pH = -log[H+] = 11.

7. Solubility

(a) Factors: temperature, pressure (for gases), nature of solute and solvent.
(b) Mass % = (mass solute / total mass solution) × 100 = (20 / (20 + 100)) × 100 = 16.67%.

8. Oxidation and reduction

(a) Oxidation: loss of electrons (Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻). Reduction: gain of electrons (Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu).
(b) Cr in K2Cr2O7: Let x = oxidation number of Cr. 2K⁺ (+1) + 2Cr + 7O²⁻ (-14) = 0 → 2 + 2x -14 = 0 → 2x = 12 → x = +6.

9. Electrolysis of aqueous CuSO4

(a) Cathode: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu (deposited). Anode: Cu → Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻.
(b) Cathode: copper metal, Anode: copper ions into solution.

10. Preparation of 1 M HCl

(a) Dilution formula: C1V1 = C2V2 → 12 × V1 = 1 × 0.25 → V1 = 0.02083 L ≈ 20.8 cm³. Measure 20.8 cm³ concentrated HCl, dilute to 250 cm³ with water.
(b) Precautions: wear gloves/goggles; add acid to water slowly.

SECTION C

11. Standardization of NaOH

(a) Steps: weigh known mass of oxalic acid, dissolve in water, fill burette with NaOH, titrate until phenolphthalein changes colour.
(b) Reaction: H2C2O4 + 2NaOH → Na2C2O4 + 2H2O.
(c) Calculate concentration: moles oxalic acid reacted = mass / molar mass, use stoichiometry to find moles NaOH, then divide by volume used to get molarity.
Explanation: Titre readings give volume of NaOH needed to neutralize known moles of acid.
